title: --watch-files doesn't work with Scala files
body:
### Issue

Scala supports '//' style comments just like Java so it could be added to the corresponding list of file extensions so that "Aider in your IDE" works.

### Version and model info

aider-chat                           0.68.0
author: pkozikow

comments.body:
This should be fixed in the latest version. You can get it like this:

```
aider --upgrade

# or...

python -m pip install --upgrade --upgrade-strategy only-if-needed aider-chat
```

If you have a chance to try it, let me know if it works better for you.

See #2586
@paul-gauthier  I recommend allowing a user-defined trigger. Or something like `@aider` anywhere within the file.

title: Q?: Why is the cache being warmed with 23K when I have no files loaded?
body:
### Issue

I was using aider for a few minutes and then the phone rang.  I knew it might be a longer call so I decided to drop my files from the chat, thinking that if I was sitting idle at the prompt with no files loaded, it wouldn't need anything warm in the cache.  

Then I came back to this on the console, which lead to some questions:

```
> /drop aider/coders/chat_chunks.py                                                                                                                                                                              

Removed aider/coders/chat_chunks.py from the chat
─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
> Warmed 21k cached tokens.
Warmed 21k cached tokens.
Warmed 0 cached tokens.
Warmed 21k cached tokens.                                                                                                                                                                                        
Warmed 21k cached tokens.
Warmed 21k cached tokens.
Warmed 21k cached tokens.
Warmed 21k cached tokens.
Warmed 21k cached tokens.
Warmed 21k cached tokens.
Warmed 21k cached tokens.
Warmed 21k cached tokens.
Warmed 21k cached tokens.
Warmed 21k cached tokens.
Warmed 21k cached tokens.
Warmed 21k cached tokens.
Warmed 21k cached tokens.
Warmed 21k cached tokens.
Warmed 21k cached tokens.
Warmed 21k cached tokens.
Warmed 21k cached tokens.
```
Does it make sense to be keeping the cache warm when there are no files?  I am assuming the 21K must be chat history and other hidden prompt things and the repo-map?

Also, this sequence jumped out at me, any idea what is happening here?

```
Warmed 21k cached tokens.
Warmed 0 cached tokens.
Warmed 21k cached tokens. 
```  

### Version and model info

Aider v0.60.1
Main model: claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022 with diff edit format, prompt cache, infinite output
Weak model: claude-3-haiku-20240307
Git repo: .git with 361 files
Repo-map: using 1024 tokens, files refresh

aider 0.54.12
--sonnet

_No response_
author: 5ocworkshop

comments.body:
Thanks for trying aider and filing this issue.

The output will be sent along with your next chat message.

Ah so there is a subtle difference in the almost identical prompt to what happens when you receive output using /run versus when the prompt itself sets you up to run?  Using run, when prompted, will submit the results as the next prompt when you say Yes.  If you accept the running of the command triggered from the previous prompt, and you say Yes, it will append the output to your next message but you still have the interactive opportunity to add things to the message?

Maybe the wording could be slightly different from Aider when it asks what you want to do in these two cases?
Yes, that's correct. I agree, it's currently a bit confusing.
